markdownRemark.html:
Preface

This article aims to provide some of the derivations from Ioannidis' 2005 article: "Why Most Published Research Findings Are False" which exposed what has since been termed "The Replication Crisis."

The issue begins with the subject of ppp-values which measure the probability of a study finding a positive result, assuming the presented hypothesis is false. A strong ppp-values is considered to be 0.050.050.05, indicating a regrettable 5% of published findings are false.

Before diving into the derivations, some examples:

Example 1

Suppose we represent all possible hypotheses that can be tested with a more manageable 100,000 hypotheses. Let's allow a generous 50:50 true:false split for this set as well as a statistical power of 80%.

True False Total
positive result +++ 40k 2.5k 42.5k
negative result −-− 10k 47.5k 57.5k
Total 50k 50k 100k

Here, the ppp-value =α=P(+∣ f )= \alpha = P(+ \vert \text{ f })=α=P(+∣ f ) where +++ is a positive relationship, and f\text{f}f is a flase result. The statistical power =P(+∣ t )= P(+ \vert \text{ t })=P(+∣ t ) and Positive Predictive Value PPV=statistical powerP( t + f ∣+)=40k42.5k≈0.94\text{PPV} = \frac{\text{statistical power}}{P(\text{ t } + \text{ f } \vert +)} = \frac{40k}{42.5k} \approx 0.94PPV=P( t + f ∣+)statistical power​=42.5k40k​≈0.94 which is pretty satisfactory given our generous values.

Example 2

Once again, we'll take 100,000 hypotheses, but now with a 10:90 true:false split for this set as well as a statistical power of 80%. Filling out the table we get:

True False Total
+++ 8k 4.5k 12.5k
−-− 2k 85.5k 87.5k
Total 10k 90k 100k

Here, PPV=8k12.5k=0.64\text{PPV} = \frac{8k}{12.5k} = 0.64PPV=12.5k8k​=0.64 which is significantly worse than the assumed 95% if the study is positive without publicaiton bias, cheating etc. which is covered below.

Before getting much further, it will be useful to define a glossary

Symbol Value Meaning
ppp P(+∣ f )P(+ \vert \text{ f })P(+∣ f ) probability of a study finding a positive result, given that the hypothesis is false
PPV\text{PPV}PPV statistical powerP( t + f ∣+)\frac{\text{statistical power}}{P(\text{ t } + \text{ f } \vert +)}P( t + f ∣+)statistical power​ Positive Predictive Value
RRR P( t )P( f )\frac{P(\text{ t } )}{P(\text{ f } )}P( f )P( t )​ the pre-study odds of the hypothesis is tested
Θ\varThetaΘ =R=P1−P= R = \frac{P}{1 - P}=R=1−PP​ an alternate expression of probability, e.g. 10:90 odds: Θ=10%100%−10%\varTheta = \frac{10\%}{100\% - 10\%}Θ=100%−10%10%​
P(f)P(\text{f})P(f) 1−P( t )1 - P(\text{ t })1−P( t ) compliment rule
α\alphaα P(+∣ f )P( + \vert \text{ f })P(+∣ f ) Type I Error
β\betaβ P(−∣ t )P( - \vert \text{ t })P(−∣ t ) Type II Error
P(t ∣+)P(\text{t } \vert +)P(t ∣+) P(t)⋅P(+∣ t )P(t)\frac{P(\text{t}) \cdot P(+ \vert \text{ t })}{P(t)}P(t)P(t)⋅P(+∣ t )​ Bayes Rule
P(t∧+)P(\text{t} \land +)P(t∧+) P( t ∣+)⋅P(t)P(\text{ t } \vert +) \cdot P(\text{t})P( t ∣+)⋅P(t) Product Rule
uuu bias factor influenced by ppp-hacking, conflict of interest, competitive publication motivations, etc.

Table 1

Now we can recreate the general table for all such examples above and derive their values:

True False Total
+++ c(1−β)RR+1\frac{c(1 - \beta)R}{R+1}R+1c(1−β)R​ cαR+1\frac{c \alpha}{R+1}R+1cα​ c(R+α−βR)R+1\frac{c(R+\alpha-\beta R)}{R+1}R+1c(R+α−βR)​
−-− cβRR+1\frac{c \beta R}{R+1}R+1cβR​ c(1−α)R+1\frac{c(1-\alpha)}{R+1}R+1c(1−α)​ c(1−α+βR)R+1\frac{c(1-\alpha + \beta R)}{R+1}R+1c(1−α+βR)​
Total cRR+1\frac{cR}{R+1}R+1cR​ cR+1\frac{c}{R+1}R+1c​ ccc the number of relationships tested

Derivations

Starting with the top left cell which represents:

P(+∧ t )=P(+∣ t )⏟§⋅P(t)⏟RR+1P(+ \land \text{ t }) = \underbrace{P(+ \vert \text{ t })}_{\text{\S}} \cdot \underbrace{P(\text{t})}_{\frac{R}{R+1}}P(+∧ t )=§P(+∣ t )​​⋅R+1R​P(t)​​

§1.1:β=P(−∣ t )\quad \text{\S} 1.1: \beta = P(- \vert \text{ t })§1.1:β=P(−∣ t )

§1.2:P(+∣ t )+P(−∣ t )=1\quad \text{\S} 1.2: P(+ \vert \text{ t }) + P(- \vert \text{ t }) = 1§1.2:P(+∣ t )+P(−∣ t )=1

§1.3:P(+∣ t )+P(−∣ t )=1\quad \text{\S} 1.3: P(+ \vert \text{ t }) + P(- \vert \text{ t }) = 1§1.3:P(+∣ t )+P(−∣ t )=1

§∴P(+∣ t )=1−β\quad \text{\S} \therefore P(+ \vert \text{ t }) = 1 - \beta§∴P(+∣ t )=1−β

=(1−β)(RR+1)=c(1−β)RR+1= (1- \beta )(\frac{R}{R+1})= \frac{c(1 - \beta )R}{R+1}=(1−β)(R+1R​)=R+1c(1−β)R​

Similarly, for the top-middle cell:

P(+∧ f )=P(+∣ f )⏟α⋅P(f)⏟1−RR+1P(+ \land \text{ f }) = \underbrace{P(+ \vert \text{ f })}_{\alpha} \cdot \underbrace{P(\text{f})}_{1 - \frac{R}{R+1}}P(+∧ f )=αP(+∣ f )​​⋅1−R+1R​P(f)​​

=α(1−RR+1)=cαR+1= \alpha (1 - \frac{R}{R+1}) = \frac{c \alpha}{R+1}=α(1−R+1R​)=R+1cα​

So, for all true positives, the top-right cell:

true positivesall positives=c(1−β)RR+1c(R+α−βR)R+1=(1−β)RR+α−βR=P( t ∣+)⏟want this bad boi to be high\frac{\text{true positives}}{{\text{all positives}}} = \frac{\frac{c(1- \beta )R}{R+1}}{\frac{c(R+ \alpha - \beta R)}{R+1}} = \frac{(1 - \beta ) R}{ R + \alpha - \beta R} = \underbrace{P(\text{ t } \vert +)}_{\text {want this bad boi to be high}}all positivestrue positives​=R+1c(R+α−βR)​R+1c(1−β)R​​=R+α−βR(1−β)R​=want this bad boi to be highP( t ∣+)​​ in terms of Type I, II error and pre-study odds.

When is a Study More Likely to be True than False?

P( t ∣+)>12P(\text{ t } \vert +) > \frac{1}{2}P( t ∣+)>21​

⇒(1−β)RR+α−βR>12\rArr \frac{(1 - \beta ) R}{ R + \alpha - \beta R} > \frac{1}{2}⇒R+α−βR(1−β)R​>21​

⇒2((1−β)RR+α−βR)>2(12)\rArr 2(\frac{(1 - \beta ) R}{ R + \alpha - \beta R}) > 2( \frac{1}{2})⇒2(R+α−βR(1−β)R​)>2(21​)

⇒2(1−β)R>R+α−βR\rArr 2(1 - \beta )R > R + \alpha - \beta R⇒2(1−β)R>R+α−βR

⇒R(1−β)>α  ⟺  (pre-study odds)(statistical power)>p-value\rArr R(1 - \beta ) > \alpha \iff (\text{pre-study odds})(\text{statistical power}) > p\text{-value}⇒R(1−β)>α⟺(pre-study odds)(statistical power)>p-value

Some fields of study have inherently small RRR or (1−β)(1 - \beta)(1−β) values

What Happens if we Introduce Bias?

P(+∧ f )=P(+∣ f )⋅P(f)⟶biasP(+ \land \text{ f }) = P(+ \vert \text{ f }) \cdot P(\text{f}) \underset{bias}{\longrightarrow}P(+∧ f )=P(+∣ f )⋅P(f)bias⟶​ negative study results become positive with P(u)P(u)P(u)

This can alter our outcome by in two cases:

1. P(+⏟for any reason∧t)\text{1. } P(\underbrace{+}_{\text{for any reason}} \land \text{t})1. P(for any reason+​​∧t)

=P(+∣ t )⏟1−β⋅P(t)⏟RR+1+u⋅P(−∣ t )⏟Type II Error: β⋅P(t)= \underbrace{P(+ \vert \text{ t })}_{1 - \beta} \cdot \underbrace{P(\text{t})}_{\frac{R}{R+1}} + u \cdot \underbrace{P(- \vert \text{ t })}_{\text{Type II Error: } \beta} \cdot P(\text{t})=1−βP(+∣ t )​​⋅R+1R​P(t)​​+u⋅Type II Error: βP(−∣ t )​​⋅P(t)

=(1−β)(RR+1)+uβRR+1= (1 - \beta )(\frac{R}{R+1}) + u \beta \frac{R}{R+1}=(1−β)(R+1R​)+uβR+1R​

=1−βR+uβRR+1= \frac{1 - \beta R + u \beta R}{R+1}=R+11−βR+uβR​

2. P(+⏟for any reason∧f)\text{2. } P(\underbrace{+}_{\text{for any reason}} \land \text{f})2. P(for any reason+​​∧f)

=P(+∣ f )⋅P(f)⏟1−P(t)+u⋅P(−∣ f )⋅P(f)= P(+ \vert \text{ f }) \cdot \underbrace{P(\text{f})}_{1-P(t)} + u \cdot P(- \vert \text{ f }) \cdot P(\text{f})=P(+∣ f )⋅1−P(t)P(f)​​+u⋅P(−∣ f )⋅P(f)

=α(1−RR+1)+u(1−α)(1−RR+1)= \alpha (1-\frac{R}{R+1}) + u(1 - \alpha)(1-\frac{R}{R+1})=α(1−R+1R​)+u(1−α)(1−R+1R​) Note that these truths/falsehoods have to be independent of the decision making otherwise they would impair judgement, disallowing us from applying the Product Rule

=α+u(1−α)R+1= \frac{\alpha + u(1 - \alpha)}{R+1}=R+1α+u(1−α)​

The Issue of Incorrect pre-publication ppp-values.

Research efforts do not occur in isolation. Several teams may be independently, competitive working on the same hypotheses over and over and over again without adjusting their ppp-values.

Relevant xkcd:

This means that statistical power decreases as the experiments are repeated:

P(+>0⏟with n studies∧ t )P(\underbrace{+_{\tiny > 0}}_{\text{with n studies}} \land \text{ t })P(with n studies+>0​​​∧ t )

=P(+⏟§∧ t )⋅P(t)= P(\underbrace{+}_{\text{\S}} \land \text{ t }) \cdot P(\text{t})=P(§+​​∧ t )⋅P(t)

§2.1:P(+∧ t )=∑nPn\quad \text{\S}2.1: P(+ \land \text{ t }) = \displaystyle\sum^{n} P_n§2.1:P(+∧ t )=∑n​Pn​ which could be ... a lot of probabilities

§2.2:(1−P(−∀n∣ t ))⋅P(t)\quad \text{\S}2.2: (1 - P(-_{\forall \tiny n} \vert \text{ t })) \cdot P(\text{t})§2.2:(1−P(−∀n​∣ t ))⋅P(t) which is the negative results of all nnn studies

§2.3:(1−βn)⋅P(t)\quad \text{\S}2.3: (1 - \beta^n) \cdot P(\text{t})§2.3:(1−βn)⋅P(t)

=R(1−βn)R+1= \frac{R(1 - \beta^n)}{R+1}=R+1R(1−βn)​

Meaning that for each subsequent, competing trial, the likelihood of your own ppp-value genuinely being sufficiently small decreases.
